channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: After decades on NPR, this familiar voice is retiring
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro and longtime newscaster Jack Speer chat about his early years covering business for the network, his retirement, and what he'll miss about covering the daily news.

item.title: The professor behind the 'power nap,' James Maas, dies at 86
item.description: Renowned social psychologist James Maas was on a mission to get Americans to take sleep more seriously. The longtime Cornell professor credited with coining the term "power nap" died last week at 86.

item.title: A Ukrainian actress saw herself in a White House video -- and created one in response
item.description: Antonina Khyzhniak, who appeared in stock footage included in a White House Instagram video for the Trump administration's tax bill, responded with a humorous video — and a serious message.

item.title: Sen. John Thune, once a political enemy of Trump, emerges as a key ally
item.description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune is a key ally of President Trump's, helping get his domestic policy bill passed by the Senate. It is a dramatic reversal from their days as virtual political enemies.

item.title: Rep. Mike Lawler on the GOP's spending bill, and whether the House can pass it
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers talks with New York Rep. Mike Lawler, a republican, about the Senate's tax and spending bill – and whether he thinks the House has enough votes to send it to the president's desk.

item.title: A Green Day fan invited onstage to play one of their songs plays 'Wonderwall' instead
item.description: A fan at a Green Day concert was invited onstage to play along with the band — only to start playing someone else's music.

item.title: Pre Civil-War Wisconsin law does not ban abortion, says state Supreme Court
item.description: A law from 1849 does not ban abortion in Wisconsin. That's what the state Supreme Court decided Wednesday.

item.title: The Dalai Lama's succession
item.description: As Dalai Lama turns 90, he says he will not be the last spiritual leader of Tibet's Buddhists — there will be a successor.

item.title: Proposed Medicaid cuts threaten the future of Kentucky health clinics
item.description: A look at a rural clinic in Kentucky shows how it could get harder for states to provide health care for people on Medicaid — and how other clinics could be affected — if Congress imposes cuts.

item.title: The Senate bill and the social safety net
item.description: President Trump's sweeping domestic policy bill passed the Senate. It would cut trillions in taxes. It also would make the biggest cuts to the social safety net in decades — to things like food aid.
